<ce:section-title id="st005">Graphical abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0005" view="all">Three new superoxide dismutase mimetics with perfect SOD activity were discovered. <ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Three new superoxide dismutase model compounds: [CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [PbL] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>).</ce:para><ce:para id="p0010" view="all">Superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity.</ce:para><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Relationship between structure and SOD activity.</ce:para><ce:section-title id="st015">Abstract</ce:section-title><ce:simple-para id="sp0020" view="all">Three new superoxide dismutase model compounds: [CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [PbL] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) were successfully synthesized by the reaction of a transition metal salt and 5-aminoisophthalic acid under hydrothermal conditions (L: 5-aminoisophthalic acid). The three compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, ultraviolet–visible spectroscopy, PXRD analysis and TG analysis. X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis showed that compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were 3D inorganic–organic framework structures while compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was a 2D structure. These simulations contained pores structures with maximum sizes of 4.08–14.67 Å. To further explore the functional properties of these compounds, we firstly analyzed their SOD activity, and the results demonstrated that they have different SOD activities. The IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> values of the three mimics are much smaller than the international standard for SOD standards, demonstrating that these mimics have superior Reactive Oxygen Species resistance.</ce:simple-para>
elements.clean_text:
Three new superoxide dismutase model compounds: [CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1), [CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) and [PbL] (3).

Superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity.

Relationship between structure and SOD activity.

Abstract

Three new superoxide dismutase model compounds: [CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1), [CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) and [PbL] (3) were successfully synthesized by the reaction of a transition metal salt and 5-aminoisophthalic acid under hydrothermal conditions (L: 5-aminoisophthalic acid). The three compounds were characterized by elemental analysis, infrared spectroscopy, ultraviolet-visible spectroscopy, PXRD analysis and TG analysis. X-ray single crystal diffraction analysis showed that compounds 2 and 3 were 3D inorganic-organic framework structures while compound 1 was a 2D structure. These simulations contained pores structures with maximum sizes of 4.08-14.67Å. To further explore the functional properties of these compounds, we firstly analyzed their SOD activity, and the results demonstrated that they have different SOD activities. The IC50 values of the three mimics are much smaller than the international standard for SOD standards, demonstrating that these mimics have superior Reactive Oxygen Species resistance.

<ce:section-title id="st025">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) is a generic term for oxygenates in organisms. It includes oxygen and oxygen-containing highly reactive molecules (such as superoxide anion radicals, singlet oxygen and tissue peroxides, etc.) . The superoxide anion radical (O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>−</ce:sup>) is a product of electron reduction of molecular oxygen . It not only has a long life, oxidation and reduction properties, but also reacts with hydrogen peroxide to generate hydroxyl radicals (OH<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>) . Because hydroxyl radicals (OH<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>) often give rise to serious damage to the organism, such as body inflammation, cancer and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and so on . Therefore, the study of the removal of superoxide anion radicals in the body has become an important part of contemporary chemical research.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS) is a generic term for oxygenates in organisms. It includes oxygen and oxygen-containing highly reactive molecules (such as superoxide anion radicals, singlet oxygen and tissue peroxides, etc.) . The superoxide anion radical (O2  -) is a product of electron reduction of molecular oxygen . It not only has a long life, oxidation and reduction properties, but also reacts with hydrogen peroxide to generate hydroxyl radicals (OH) . Because hydroxyl radicals (OH) often give rise to serious damage to the organism, such as body inflammation, cancer and amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) and so on . Therefore, the study of the removal of superoxide anion radicals in the body has become an important part of contemporary chemical research.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0025" view="all">Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is an enzyme widely found in living organisms. It can be used to catalyze superoxide anion radical (O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>−</ce:sup>) by disproportionation, which has been widely studied . The SOD is called “the scavenger of the human body” in medical field, which has prominent features in anti-aging, anti-radiation and anti-virus, etc. The structure of SOD is generally that metal ions coordinate with N/O/S atoms in organic substances in the human body to form compounds and the harm is reduced by acting on the superoxide anion radical (O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">
<ce:glyph name="rad"></ce:glyph>−</ce:sup>) in the body. However, due to the high cost and low stability of natural SOD, its application is limited. Therefore, in order to overcome these shortcomings, synthesizing superoxide dismutase mimetics by the help of coordination chemistry has become a hot topic in current chemical research (Principle details as demonstrate in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>.) . In recent decades, as a new type of the functional materials, metal–organic framework materials (MOFs) have become a research hotspot because of their adjustable pore structure and stable skeleton structure , its coordination mode coincides with our conception of superoxide dismutase mimics.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: Superoxide dismutase (SOD) is an enzyme widely found in living organisms. It can be used to catalyze superoxide anion radical (O2  -) by disproportionation, which has been widely studied . The SOD is called "the scavenger of the human body" in medical field, which has prominent features in anti-aging, anti-radiation and anti-virus, etc. The structure of SOD is generally that metal ions coordinate with N/O/S atoms in organic substances in the human body to form compounds and the harm is reduced by acting on the superoxide anion radical (O2  -) in the body. However, due to the high cost and low stability of natural SOD, its application is limited. Therefore, in order to overcome these shortcomings, synthesizing superoxide dismutase mimetics by the help of coordination chemistry has become a hot topic in current chemical research (Principle details as demonstrate in  .) . In recent decades, as a new type of the functional materials, metal-organic framework materials (MOFs) have become a research hotspot because of their adjustable pore structure and stable skeleton structure , its coordination mode coincides with our conception of superoxide dismutase mimics.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0030" view="all">In recent years, in addition to CuZn-SODs, Fe-SOD and Mn-SOD , a new superoxide dismutase mimics (SODs) have been synthesized, namely Ni-SOD . The SOD activity of these compounds was also measured. Their inhibition rate was plotted against the concentration of the mixed solution, which revealed the SOD activity of the compound. The concentration value of the compound corresponding to the inhibition rate on the curve of 50% is the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value of the compound. Under the same conditions, the internationally specified normal IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value is 32 mg/L. The smaller the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value, the better the SOD activity of the compounds .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In recent years, in addition to CuZn-SODs, Fe-SOD and Mn-SOD , a new superoxide dismutase mimics (SODs) have been synthesized, namely Ni-SOD . The SOD activity of these compounds was also measured. Their inhibition rate was plotted against the concentration of the mixed solution, which revealed the SOD activity of the compound. The concentration value of the compound corresponding to the inhibition rate on the curve of 50% is the IC50 value of the compound. Under the same conditions, the internationally specified normal IC50 value is 32mg/L. The smaller the IC50 value, the better the SOD activity of the compounds .

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In the active center of simulant structures, the coordination atoms surrounding active center involve oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur atom, etc. Notably, nitrogen containing organic carboxylic acid molecule is a typical example, which is frequently reported in the literatures . Therefore, we chose the simplest nitrogen-containing ligand 5-aminoisophthalic acid to constructed three SODs with a series of transition metal ions and studied their SOD activity. As far as we know, some compounds related to 5-aminoisophthalic acid were reported, but their superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity is not studied . A part of as our continue studying synthesis and functional properties of the coordination polymers with 5-aminoisophthalic acid, here, we reported three new superoxide dismutase mimics: [CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [PbL] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>), as well as bioactivity. The structure of the ligand (L) is presented in the 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>. The IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> values of the three compounds were all less than 32 mg/L, and the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> values reported in related literatures were smaller, demonstrating that these three compounds have better SOD activity.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In the active center of simulant structures, the coordination atoms surrounding active center involve oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur atom, etc. Notably, nitrogen containing organic carboxylic acid molecule is a typical example, which is frequently reported in the literatures . Therefore, we chose the simplest nitrogen-containing ligand 5-aminoisophthalic acid to constructed three SODs with a series of transition metal ions and studied their SOD activity. As far as we know, some compounds related to 5-aminoisophthalic acid were reported, but their superoxide dismutase (SOD) activity is not studied . A part of as our continue studying synthesis and functional properties of the coordination polymers with 5-aminoisophthalic acid, here, we reported three new superoxide dismutase mimics: [CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1), [CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) and [PbL] (3), as well as bioactivity. The structure of the ligand (L) is presented in the  . The IC50 values of the three compounds were all less than 32mg/L, and the IC50 values reported in related literatures were smaller, demonstrating that these three compounds have better SOD activity.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st030">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">Ligand L is commercially available, and all other chemicals are chemically pure or better and used without further purification. All IR measurements were obtained by using a Bruker AXS TENSOR-27 FT-IR spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the range of 400–4000 cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at room temperature. UV–Vis–NIR spectra for compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and the L ligand were recorded on a JASCO V-570 UV/Vis/NIR microspectrophotometer (200–2500 nm). Elemental analyses of C, H and N were conducted on a PerkinElmer 240C automatic analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed on a PerkinElmer Diamond TG/DTA under atmosphere from room temperature to 800 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern was obtained on a Advance-D8 equipped with Cu Ka radiation in the range 5° < 2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic> < 55°, with a step size of 0.02° (2<ce:italic>θ</ce:italic>) and a count time of 2 s/step.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

Ligand L is commercially available, and all other chemicals are chemically pure or better and used without further purification. All IR measurements were obtained by using a Bruker AXS TENSOR-27 FT-IR spectrometer with pressed KBr pellets in the range of 400-4000cm-1 at room temperature. UV-Vis-NIR spectra for compounds 1-3 and the L ligand were recorded on a JASCO V-570 UV/Vis/NIR microspectrophotometer (200-2500nm). Elemental analyses of C, H and N were conducted on a PerkinElmer 240C automatic analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TG) was performed on a PerkinElmer Diamond TG/DTA under atmosphere from room temperature to 800°C with a heating rate of 10°C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction pattern was obtained on a Advance-D8 equipped with Cu Ka radiation in the range 5°<2θ<55°, with a step size of 0.02° (2θ) and a count time of 2s/step.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">Preparation of the model compounds</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">[CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.0588 g, 0.2 mmol), L (0.0543 g, 0.3 mmol) and TMC (0.0265 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 3 mL EtOH, 1 mL H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 1 mL DMF. The pH of the solution was adjusted with dilute nitric acid to make the pH equal to 5. The solution is stirred for 2 h at room temperature to give a pink suspension, which was transferred to a reaction pyrex vial and heated at 120 °C for 5 days. After cooled to room temperature, pink bulk crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.046 g; 41% (based on Co (II)). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">10</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>Co: C, 32.59; H, 4.39; N, 4.81. Found: C, 32.64; H, 4.42; N, 4.76%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3427, 3221, 3275, 2926, 2869, 1620, 1563, 1417, 1335, 1131, 1099, 1037, 783.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of the model compounds

[CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1) Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0588g, 0.2mmol), L (0.0543g, 0.3mmol) and TMC (0.0265g, 0.1mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 3mL EtOH, 1mL H2O and 1mL DMF. The pH of the solution was adjusted with dilute nitric acid to make the pH equal to 5. The solution is stirred for 2h at room temperature to give a pink suspension, which was transferred to a reaction pyrex vial and heated at 120°C for 5days. After cooled to room temperature, pink bulk crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.046g; 41% (based on Co (II)). Calc. for C8H10NO7Co: C, 32.59; H, 4.39; N, 4.81. Found: C, 32.64; H, 4.42; N, 4.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3427, 3221, 3275, 2926, 2869, 1620, 1563, 1417, 1335, 1131, 1099, 1037, 783.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0050" view="all">[CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.0588 g, 0.2 mmol), L (0.0543 g, 0.3 mmol) and TMC (Trimesoyl chloride) (0.0265 g, 0.1 mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 4 mL EtOH, 1 mL H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and 2 mL DMF. To adjust the pH of the solution with dilute nitric acid so that pH equal to 4. Stirring at room temperature for 2 h, a colorless transparent solution is obtained. Transfer the solution to a heat-resistant vial and heated at 140 °C for 2 days. After cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.054 g; 39% (based on Cd (II)). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">8</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>Cd: C, 29.32; H, 2.69; N, 4.31. Found: C, 29.31; H, 2.75; N, 4.27%. IR (KBr, cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3336, 3216, 3139, 2920, 2861, 1617, 1549, 1476, 1383, 1153, 1066, 1014, 780.</ce:para>

To adjust the pH of the solution with dilute nitric acid so that pH equal to 4. Stirring at room temperature for 2h, a colorless transparent solution is obtained. Transfer the solution to a heat-resistant vial and heated at 140°C for 2days. After cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.054g; 39% (based on Cd (II)). Calc. for C8H9NO6Cd: C, 29.32; H, 2.69; N, 4.31. Found: C, 29.31; H, 2.75; N, 4.27%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3336, 3216, 3139, 2920, 2861, 1617, 1549, 1476, 1383, 1153, 1066, 1014, 780.

elements.content: <ce:para id="p0055" view="all">[PbL] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) PbSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.0304 g, 0.1 mmol) and L (0.0362 g, 0.2 mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 2 mL EtOH and 3 mL DMA. Stirring at room temperature for 2 h to give a white suspension, which was transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 4 days. Stirring at room temperature for 2h to give a white suspension, which was transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 120°C for 4days. After cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.019g; 28% (based on Pb (II)). Calc. for C8H5NO4Pb: C, 24.82; H, 1.79; N, 3.65. Found: C, 24.85; H, 1.81; N, 3.62%. elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st045">X-ray crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">Single crystals of three compounds were respectively selected and adhered to glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic> = 0.71073 Å). All the measured independent reflections (<ce:italic>I</ce:italic> > 2<ce:italic>σ</ce:italic>(<ce:italic>I</ce:italic>)) were used in the structural analyses, and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program . The structure was solved by direct methods using the <ce:small-caps>shelx</ce:small-caps>-97 program . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the organic frameworks were geometrically fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The crystallographic data for compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in . The selected bond distances (Å) of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are given in . The hydrogen bond lengths (Å) and bond angles (°) of the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>2</ce:bold> are given in .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
X-ray crystal structure determination

Single crystals of three compounds were respectively selected and adhered to glass fibers for X-ray measurement. Reflection data were collected at room temperature on a Bruker AXS SMART APEX II CCD diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å). All the measured independent reflections (I>2σ(I)) were used in the structural analyses, and semi-empirical absorption corrections were applied using the SADABS program . The structure was solved by direct methods using the shelx-97 program . All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms of the organic frameworks were geometrically fixed at calculated positions and refined using a riding model. The crystallographic data for compound 1-3 are given in . The selected bond distances (Å) of compounds 1-3 are given in . The hydrogen bond lengths (Å) and bond angles (°) of the compounds 1-2 are given in .

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st050">Antioxidant activity measurement</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st055">Solution preparation</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0065" view="all">Preparation of Tris solution (0.1 mol/L): Weigh 1.2114 g of tris-hydroxymethyl aminomethane (Tris) in a beaker and dilute to 100 mL with double distilled water. Preparation of hydrochloric acid solution “A” (0.1 mol/L): Pipette 0.83 mL of hydrochloric acid (37%) in a beaker and dilute to 100 mL with double distilled water. Preparation of hydrochloric acid solution “B” (0.01 mol/L): Take 10 mL of hydrochloric acid solution “A” and diluted to 100 mL with distilled water. The Tris–HCl buffer solution (0.1 mol/L) was prepared: 50 mL of Tris solution and 22.9 mL of hydrochloric acid “A” solution were mixed and transferred to a 100 mL volumetric flask with the pH of 8.2. Pyrogallol solution (3 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> mol/L): Weigh 0.003783 g of pyrogallol added to 10 mL of hydrochloric acid “B” solution.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Antioxidant activity measurement

Solution preparation

Preparation of Tris solution (0.1mol/L): Weigh 1.2114g of tris-hydroxymethyl aminomethane (Tris) in a beaker and dilute to 100mL with double distilled water. Preparation of hydrochloric acid solution "A" (0.1mol/L): Pipette 0.83mL of hydrochloric acid (37%) in a beaker and dilute to 100mL with double distilled water. Preparation of hydrochloric acid solution "B" (0.01mol/L): Take 10mL of hydrochloric acid solution "A" and diluted to 100mL with distilled water. The Tris-HCl buffer solution (0.1mol/L) was prepared: 50mL of Tris solution and 22.9mL of hydrochloric acid "A" solution were mixed and transferred to a 100mL volumetric flask with the pH of 8.2. Pyrogallol solution (3×10-3 mol/L): Weigh 0.003783g of pyrogallol added to 10mL of hydrochloric acid "B" solution.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st060">Measurement procedure</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0070" view="all">Mixed 5 mL 0.1 mol/L Tris–HCl buffer solution and 4.7 mL double distilled water together, and kept in a 25 °C water bath for 20 min. Then removed the mixture and immediately added 0.3 mL of pyrogallol (3 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> mol/L) preheated at 25 °C, shook well and pour into the cuvette. The sample was scanned at a wavelength of 200 nm to 800 nm with UV-1000 spectrophotometer. The wavelength corresponding to the maximum absorption peak of the sample was the wavelength selected for this experiment. The maximum wavelength was 319.9 nm.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Measurement procedure

Mixed 5mL 0.1mol/L Tris-HCl buffer solution and 4.7mL double distilled water together, and kept in a 25°C water bath for 20min. Then removed the mixture and immediately added 0.3mL of pyrogallol (3×10-3mol/L) preheated at 25°C, shook well and pour into the cuvette. The sample was scanned at a wavelength of 200nm to 800nm with UV-1000 spectrophotometer. The wavelength corresponding to the maximum absorption peak of the sample was the wavelength selected for this experiment. The maximum wavelength was 319.9nm.

elements.content:

Then remove the mixture and immediately add 0.3 mL of pyrogallol (3 × 10<ce:sup loc="post">−3</ce:sup> mol/L) preheated at 25 °C, shake well and pour into the cuvette. Use “B solution” as a blank reference solution to test at the maximum wavelength. Took a point at regular intervals and measured continuously for 3 min. The absorbance A was plotted against time <ce:italic>t</ce:italic>, and the slope obtained by fitting the line was taken as the auto-oxidation rate (<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">0</ce:inf>) of pyrogallol.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Determination of pyrolysis rate of pyrogallol

Take 5mL, 0.1mol/L Tris-HCl buffer solution and mix with 4.7mL of double distilled water and incubate in a 25°C water bath for 20min. Then remove the mixture and immediately add 0.3mL of pyrogallol (3×10-3mol/L) preheated at 25°C, shake well and pour into the cuvette. Use "B solution" as a blank reference solution to test at the maximum wavelength. Took a point at regular intervals and measured continuously for 3min. The absorbance A was plotted against time t, and the slope obtained by fitting the line was taken as the auto-oxidation rate (K 0) of pyrogallol.

elements.clean_text:
Determination of SOD activity

The absorbance of the crucible auto-oxidation reaction was linear with the time within 20min (the linear relationship was generally maintained for 3 to 4min). The absorbance was plotted against time and fitted to a straight line. Their slopes were the rates of auto-oxidation of pyrogallol after addition of different concentrations of the sample, respectively denoted as K 1, K 2, K 3….…K 6, K 7. The inhibition rate (η), was calculated from the resulting slope. The formula is:    η =    1 -  K i  /  K 0     × 100 %

The concentration value of the compound at the inhibition rate of 50% is the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value of the compound. The smaller the IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value, the better the simulated SOD activity of the compounds. For test results, absorbance A versus time <ce:italic>t</ce:italic> was plotted and the obtained line was fitted approximately to obtain the slope. The inhibitory rate was plotted against the concentration of the mixed solution to obtain the SOD activity curve of the compound. The concentration value of the compound at the inhibition rate of 50% is the IC50 value of the compound. The smaller the IC50 value, the better the simulated SOD activity of the compounds. For test results, absorbance A versus time t was plotted and the obtained line was fitted approximately to obtain the slope. The IC50 of various model compounds were obtained by calculation and plotting, respectively.

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st080">Result and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st085">Synthesis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0095" view="all">The compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were synthesized by the reaction of Co(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, Cd(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>·4H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and PbSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> with ligand L, respectively, under the hydrothermal conditions (the synthetic route shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>), related similar four compounds (<ce:bold>4</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>7</ce:bold>) were repeated according to the literature . In the reaction conditions of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>2,</ce:bold> the molar ratio of the metals and ligands is 2:3 while the molar ratio is 1:2 in compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. In addition, the reaction temperatures of the three compounds are different. The compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was obtained in vial at 120 °C, the compounds <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> was carried out in a 25 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160 °C and the reaction temperature of compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is 140 °C. The reaction processes of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are the same. The biggest difference is that the synthesis of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> does not use DMF and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, but only 2 mL of ethanol and 3 mL of DMA. Compared to this series of differences of the reaction, we can see that the synthesis of compounds is affected by more other factors. For the compounds, different ratios of mixed solvents and temperatures may play a major role in various influencing factors. Though used ligand was the same, their reaction conditions and coordination modes with metal are different. This is mainly caused by different transition metal ions.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Result and discussion

Synthesis

The compounds 1-3 were synthesized by the reaction of Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O, Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O and PbSO4 with ligand L, respectively, under the hydrothermal conditions (the synthetic route shown in  ), related similar four compounds (4-7) were repeated according to the literature . In the reaction conditions of compound 1 and 2, the molar ratio of the metals and ligands is 2:3 while the molar ratio is 1:2 in compound 3. In addition, the reaction temperatures of the three compounds are different. The compounds 1 was obtained in vial at 120°C, the compounds 3 was carried out in a 25mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 160°C and the reaction temperature of compound 2 is 140°C. The reaction processes of 2 and 3 are the same. The biggest difference is that the synthesis of compound 3 does not use DMF and H2O, but only 2mL of ethanol and 3mL of DMA. Compared to this series of differences of the reaction, we can see that the synthesis of compounds is affected by more other factors. For the compounds, different ratios of mixed solvents and temperatures may play a major role in various influencing factors. Though used ligand was the same, their reaction conditions and coordination modes with metal are different. This is mainly caused by different transition metal ions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st090">Structure descriptions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0100" view="all">[CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) X-ray single crystal diffraction data manifest that compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> crystallized in triclinic **<ce:italic>P-1</ce:italic> with space group. The molecular structure contained one Co (II) atoms, one ligand L, one coordinating water molecule and two lattice water molecules. Among them, metal Co1 and four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3<ce:sup loc="post">#1</ce:sup>, O4<ce:sup loc="post">#2</ce:sup>) from the ligand L, one nitrogen atom (N1<ce:sup loc="post">#3</ce:sup>) from the ligand L and one oxygen atom (O5) from the coordination water forms a six-coordinate distorted octahedral configuration compound ((a)). The coordination mode of the ligand L is μ<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>-η<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>η<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>, in which O1, O2 take a bidentate coordination mode, N1, O3, O4 adopt the single tooth coordination mode ((b)). The Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond lengths were in the range of 1.979(10)–2.190(10) Å, and the Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond lengths are in the range of 2.187(12)–2.243(12) Å. They was similar to the range of bond lengths reported in the literature for Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bonds (2.098(2)–2.211(2) Å) and Co<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bonds (2.186(2) Å) .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Structure descriptions

[CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1) X-ray single crystal diffraction data manifest that compound 1 crystallized in triclinic **P-1 with space group. The molecular structure contained one Co (II) atoms, one ligand L, one coordinating water molecule and two lattice water molecules. Among them, metal Co1 and four oxygen atoms (O1, O2, O3#1, O4#2) from the ligand L, one nitrogen atom (N1#3) from the ligand L and one oxygen atom (O5) from the coordination water forms a six-coordinate distorted octahedral configuration compound ((a)). The coordination mode of the ligand L is μ4-η2η1η1, in which O1, O2 take a bidentate coordination mode, N1, O3, O4 adopt the single tooth coordination mode ((b)). The CoO bond lengths were in the range of 1.979(10)-2.190(10) Å, and the CoN bond lengths are in the range of 2.187(12)-2.243(12) Å. They was similar to the range of bond lengths reported in the literature for CoO bonds (2.098(2)-2.211(2) Å) and CoN bonds (2.186(2) Å) .

The bond length of the Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O bond is 2.243(3)–2.641(3) Å and the bond length of the Cd<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N bond is 2.243(3) Å. elements.content: <ce:para id="p0125" view="all">The structural unit [Pb(μ-COO)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>] of compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is connected via a carbon atom into a 1D chain structure ((c)) and further forms a 2D layered structure through the four oxygen atoms in the ligand L ((d)). In the 2D layered structure, two different size pore structures are included. The pore sizes are 7.05 Å ((e)) and 14.67 Å ((f)). The pore structure in (e) is formed by interconnecting two ligands L and two metal Pb atoms. The pore structure in (f) was formed by the interconnection of four ligands L and four metal Pb atoms. Finally, the 2D layered structure is connected by a nitrogen atom in the amino group of the ligand L to form a 3D network ((g)).</ce:para>

In the 2D layered structure, two different size pore structures are included. The pore sizes are 7.05Å ((e)) and 14.67Å ((f)). The pore structure in (e) is formed by interconnecting two ligands L and two metal Pb atoms. The pore structure in (f) was formed by the interconnection of four ligands L and four metal Pb atoms. Finally, the 2D layered structure is connected by a nitrogen atom in the amino group of the ligand L to form a 3D network ((g)).

elements.content:
<ce:section-title id="st095">Comparison of the structures</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0130" view="all">The structural comparison of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is manifest in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>. Among them, the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is six-coordinated distorted octahedral structure. Compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is seven-coordinate pentagonal configuration and compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal configuration. Other than that, in these compounds, although the types of hydrogen bonds are different, they all only serve as structural stability. Furthermore, it was found that the coordination modes of the carboxyl oxygen atoms in the ligand L are different, resulting in a marked difference in their filling structure. The bond length (M–N) formed by the central metal and N atom in the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is slightly longer than the bond length in the other two compounds and the bond lengths in <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are 2.186(2), 2.243(3) and 2.23(3) Å, respectively, that is bond length order: <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> > <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The reason for this rule may be due to the difference in the radius of the central metal or the difference in electronegativity or the difference in the coordination mode. Due to the different coordination modes of the carboxyl oxygen atom and the amino nitrogen atom in L, the 3D structure formed by the compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are obviously different, where the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is not 3D structure. Although compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have different structures, there are a slice of differences in the coordination modes. The coordination mode of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is that the one carboxyl groups of ligand L is bidentate coordination and the other carboxyl group is double monodentate. The coordination mode of the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> is that the one carboxyl groups of the ligand L is bidentate coordination, another is tridentate coordination. In the compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the coordination mode of the ligand is: one carboxyl group with bidentate coordination; another is double monodentate mode. Although the ligand linkage fashion is the same as structure of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, structure of <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> is different from one of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Comparison of the structures

The structural comparison of compounds 1-3 is manifest in  . Among them, the compound 1 is six-coordinated distorted octahedral structure. Compound 2 is seven-coordinate pentagonal configuration and compound 3 is penta-coordinated trigonal bipyramidal configuration. Other than that, in these compounds, although the types of hydrogen bonds are different, they all only serve as structural stability. Furthermore, it was found that the coordination modes of the carboxyl oxygen atoms in the ligand L are different, resulting in a marked difference in their filling structure. The bond length (M-N) formed by the central metal and N atom in the compound 2 is slightly longer than the bond length in the other two compounds and the bond lengths in 1, 2 and 3 are 2.186(2), 2.243(3) and 2.23(3) Å, respectively, that is bond length order: 2>3>1. The reason for this rule may be due to the difference in the radius of the central metal or the difference in electronegativity or the difference in the coordination mode. Due to the different coordination modes of the carboxyl oxygen atom and the amino nitrogen atom in L, the 3D structure formed by the compounds 2 and 3 are obviously different, where the compound 1 is not 3D structure. Although compounds 1, 2 and 3 have different structures, there are a slice of differences in the coordination modes. The coordination mode of compound 1 is that the one carboxyl groups of ligand L is bidentate coordination and the other carboxyl group is double monodentate. The coordination mode of the compound 2 is that the one carboxyl groups of the ligand L is bidentate coordination, another is tridentate coordination. In the compound 3, the coordination mode of the ligand is: one carboxyl group with bidentate coordination; another is double monodentate mode. Although the ligand linkage fashion is the same as structure of the compound 1, structure of 3 is different from one of 1.

 was the UV–Vis spectra of the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> and ligand L. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the absorption bands appearing at 217 nm and 262 nm are from ligand (LLCT) transitions. The absorption band at 307 nm was attributed to the ligand-to-metal transition (LMCT), while the metal d–d<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> transition (MMCT) has three absorption bands, which occur at 557, 616 and 1022 nm, respectively. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the absorption bands appearing at 221 nm and 256 nm were assigned to the (LLCT) transition of the ligand. The band at 310 nm was assigned to a ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transition. For compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the absorption bands at 222 nm and 255 nm are attributed to the (LLCT) transition of the ligand. The band at 308 nm was assigned to a ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transition. However, the compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> have no absorption band between 400 and 1500 nm, probably because the d orbital electrons of the central metal Cd (II) was full and therefore no d–d<ce:sup loc="post">*</ce:sup> transitions can occur. We found that the absorption bands at 200–300 nm for <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> were almost the same due to the same ligand (
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0020"></ce:float-anchor>(L)) and the absorption bands at 300–1400 nm are significantly different due to the different metals. The detailed bands for the ligand L compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold> are listed in .</ce:para>

For compound 2, the absorption bands appearing at 221nm and 256nm were assigned to the (LLCT) transition of the ligand. The band at 310nm was assigned to a ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transition. For compound 3, the absorption bands at 222nm and 255nm are attributed to the (LLCT) transition of the ligand. The band at 308nm was assigned to a ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transition. However, the compound 2 have no absorption band between 400 and 1500nm, probably because the d orbital electrons of the central metal Cd (II) was full and therefore no d-d* transitions can occur. We found that the absorption bands at 200-300nm for 1-3 were almost the same due to the same ligand ( (L)) and the absorption bands at 300-1400nm are significantly different due to the different metals. PXRD analysis

As shown in , they were the PXRD patterns of compounds 1, 2 and 3, respectively. <ce:section-title id="st115">Thermal analysis</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0150" view="all">
 demonstrated the TG curves of the compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>. For compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the first stage of weight loss occurred at 30–180 °C, the actual weight loss was 12.81% (theoretical weight loss: 12.24%), corresponding to the loss of four lattice H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The second stage of weight loss occurred at 180–240 °C, the actual weightless was 17.60% (theoretical weight loss: 18.36%), corresponding to the losing of two coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The third weightless stage occurred at 240–800 °C, corresponding to the partial collapse of the ligand L. For compound <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>, the first stage of weight loss occurred at 30–255 °C and the actual weight loss was 11.71% (theoretical weight loss: 11.00%), corresponding to losing of a coordinated H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O and a lattice H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O. The second stage of weight loss occurred at 255–600 °C, the actual weight loss was 58.82% (theoretical weight loss: 60.92%), corresponding to the ligand L skeleton collapsed, the final residue is cadmium oxide. For compound <ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the first weightless stage occurred at 30–600 °C and the actual weight loss was 52.77%, corresponding to the partial collapse of the ligand L. Comparing the weightlessness of compounds <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>–<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>, the thermal decomposition temperatures were 100 °C, 250 °C and 330 °C, respectively. Therefore, in the three compounds, <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> had the best thermal stability and <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> had the worst thermal stability.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal analysis

  demonstrated the TG curves of the compounds 1-3. For compound 1, the first stage of weight loss occurred at 30-180°C, the actual weight loss was 12.81% (theoretical weight loss: 12.24%), corresponding to the loss of four lattice H2O. The second stage of weight loss occurred at 180-240°C, the actual weightless was 17.60% (theoretical weight loss: 18.36%), corresponding to the losing of two coordinated H2O. The third weightless stage occurred at 240-800°C, corresponding to the partial collapse of the ligand L. For compound 2, the first stage of weight loss occurred at 30-255°C and the actual weight loss was 11.71% (theoretical weight loss: 11.00%), corresponding to losing of a coordinated H2O and a lattice H2O. The second stage of weight loss occurred at 255-600°C, the actual weight loss was 58.82% (theoretical weight loss: 60.92%), corresponding to the ligand L skeleton collapsed, the final residue is cadmium oxide. For compound 3, the first weightless stage occurred at 30-600°C and the actual weight loss was 52.77%, corresponding to the partial collapse of the ligand L. Comparing the weightlessness of compounds 1-3, the thermal decomposition temperatures were 100°C, 250°C and 330°C, respectively. Therefore, in the three compounds, 3 had the best thermal stability and 1 had the worst thermal stability.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st125">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0160" view="all">In this work, we successfully synthesized three new superoxide dismutase mimics, [CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [PbL] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) under hydrothermal conditions by using the reaction of transition metal salts and 5-aminoisophthalic acid (L). Single crystal diffraction analysis reveal that compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have a 3D network structures. Three kinds of the mimic compounds were tested for SOD activity by the pyrogallol method. The minimum IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value of the three mimic enzymes was 2.7 mg/L and the maximum value was 10.2 mg/L, which was less than the international standard value (32 mg/L). These results manifested that they had better SOD activity, that is, anti-ROS activity. Through the experiments, we not only added a new SOD mimetic—CdSODs, but also analyze the difference in coordination mode, which may affect the anti-ROS activity. This may provide some valuable information for future anti-aging research.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we successfully synthesized three new superoxide dismutase mimics, [CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1), [CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) and [PbL] (3) under hydrothermal conditions by using the reaction of transition metal salts and 5-aminoisophthalic acid (L). Single crystal diffraction analysis reveal that compounds 2 and 3 have a 3D network structures. Three kinds of the mimic compounds were tested for SOD activity by the pyrogallol method. The minimum IC50 value of the three mimic enzymes was 2.7mg/L and the maximum value was 10.2mg/L, which was less than the international standard value (32mg/L). These results manifested that they had better SOD activity, that is, anti-ROS activity. Through the experiments, we not only added a new SOD mimetic-CdSODs, but also analyze the difference in coordination mode, which may affect the anti-ROS activity. This may provide some valuable information for future anti-aging research.

The solution is stirred for 2 h at room temperature to give a pink suspension, which was transferred to a reaction pyrex vial and heated at 120 °C for 5 days. After cooled to room temperature, pink bulk crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.046 g; 41% (based on Co (II)). Solution with a concentration of 0.01 mol/L hydrochloric acid as a blank solution, absorbance was measured at regular intervals and measured continuously for 3 min.</ce:para>

Preparation of the model compounds

[CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1) Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0588g, 0.2mmol), L (0.0543g, 0.3mmol) and TMC (0.0265g, 0.1mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 3mL EtOH, 1mL H2O and 1mL DMF. The pH of the solution was adjusted with dilute nitric acid to make the pH equal to 5. The solution is stirred for 2h at room temperature to give a pink suspension, which was transferred to a reaction pyrex vial and heated at 120°C for 5days. After cooled to room temperature, pink bulk crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.046g; 41% (based on Co (II)). Calc. for C8H10NO7Co: C, 32.59; H, 4.39; N, 4.81. Found: C, 32.64; H, 4.42; N, 4.76%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3427, 3221, 3275, 2926, 2869, 1620, 1563, 1417, 1335, 1131, 1099, 1037, 783.

[CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) Cd(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.0588g, 0.2mmol), L (0.0543g, 0.3mmol) and TMC (Trimesoyl chloride) (0.0265g, 0.1mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 4mL EtOH, 1mL H2O and 2mL DMF. To adjust the pH of the solution with dilute nitric acid so that pH equal to 4. Stirring at room temperature for 2h, a colorless transparent solution is obtained. Transfer the solution to a heat-resistant vial and heated at 140°C for 2days. After cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.054g; 39% (based on Cd (II)). Calc. for C8H9NO6Cd: C, 29.32; H, 2.69; N, 4.31. Found: C, 29.31; H, 2.75; N, 4.27%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3336, 3216, 3139, 2920, 2861, 1617, 1549, 1476, 1383, 1153, 1066, 1014, 780.

[PbL] (3) PbSO4 (0.0304g, 0.1mmol) and L (0.0362g, 0.2mmol) were dissolved in a mixed solution of 2mL EtOH and 3mL DMA. Stirring at room temperature for 2h to give a white suspension, which was transferred to a Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 120°C for 4days. After cooled to room temperature, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield: 0.019g; 28% (based on Pb (II)). Calc. for C8H5NO4Pb: C, 24.82; H, 1.79; N, 3.65. Found: C, 24.85; H, 1.81; N, 3.62%. IR (KBr, cm-1): 3423, 3292, 3110, 2944, 2853, 1637, 1569, 1454, 1389, 1123, 1064, 1012, 778.

Antioxidant activity measurement

Solution preparation

Preparation of Tris solution (0.1mol/L): Weigh 1.2114g of tris-hydroxymethyl aminomethane (Tris) in a beaker and dilute to 100mL with double distilled water. Preparation of hydrochloric acid solution "A" (0.1mol/L): Pipette 0.83mL of hydrochloric acid (37%) in a beaker and dilute to 100mL with double distilled water. Preparation of hydrochloric acid solution "B" (0.01mol/L): Take 10mL of hydrochloric acid solution "A" and diluted to 100mL with distilled water. The Tris-HCl buffer solution (0.1mol/L) was prepared: 50mL of Tris solution and 22.9mL of hydrochloric acid "A" solution were mixed and transferred to a 100mL volumetric flask with the pH of 8.2. Pyrogallol solution (3×10-3 mol/L): Weigh 0.003783g of pyrogallol added to 10mL of hydrochloric acid "B" solution.

Preparation of compounds sample solution

Weigh 1.0mg of the compounds 1-3 dissolved in 10mL of DMF solution, constant temperature ultrasound until completely dissolved, dubbed a 100mg/L compound solution. Prepared the sample solution according to the six compositions in  , mix it with a preheated 0.3mL of 3×10-3mol/L pyrogallol at a constant temperature in a 25°C water bath and pour into a 1cm cell. Solution with a concentration of 0.01mol/L hydrochloric acid as a blank solution, absorbance was measured at regular intervals and measured continuously for 3min.

cln_elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

Three new superoxide dismutase mimetics with perfect SOD activity were discovered. Their IC50 values were less than the internationally specified values (30mg/L). Particular, the IC50 value of Cd-SOD is 2.7mg/L.

In the molecular packing, the structural unit [Co2(μ-COO)2N2O6] is connected by a carbon atom into a 1D chain structure ( (c)), and further forms a 2D layered structure by the nitrogen atom in the ligand L ((d)). In the 2D layered structure, two different size pore structures are included, with pore sizes of 4.08Å ((e)) and 7.82Å ((f)). Although the pore structure in e and f was formed by the two ligands L and two metal Co atoms connected to each other. In addition, the structure of the compound 1 contains two types of hydrogen bonds: (i) NH⋯O: N1-H1A⋯O1W#5 (#5 x, y, z-1); (ii) OH⋯O: O5-H5B⋯O2W#1 (#1 x+1, y-1, z), O1W-H7C⋯O1W#6 (#6 -x+1, -y+1, -z+1). The detailed hydrogen bonds were listed in .

[CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) Structural analysis manifested that compound 2 crystallized in orthorhombic system with Pmmn space group. The molecular structure contained one Cd (II) atom, one ligand L, one coordinating water molecules and one lattice water molecules. Each center metal Cd (II) and five oxygen atoms (O1, O1#3, O2, O3#1, O4#1) from the ligand L, one nitrogen atom (N1#2) from the ligand L and one oxygen atom (O5) from the coordination water forms a seven-coordinate twisted pentagonal bipyramid configuration compound ( (a)). Among them, the coordination mode of the ligand L is μ4-η2η2η1η1, in which O2 and O1 took a unidentate/bidentate coordination mode, O3 takes a double-tooth coordination mode and N1 adopts a unidentate coordination mode (.(b)). The bond length of the CdO bond is 2.243(3)-2.641(3) Å and the bond length of the CdN bond is 2.243(3) Å. This is similar to the range of bond lengths reported in the literature for CdO bonds (2.272(6)-2.508(7) Å) and CdN bonds (2.319(7) Å) .

The structural unit [CdNO6] of compound 2 is connected by a carbon atom from the ligand into a 1D chain structure ((c)) and further forms a 2D layered structure through the nitrogen atom in the ligand L ((d)). Finally, the 2D layered structure is joined by the carboxyl oxygen atom of the ligand L to form a 3D network structure ((f)). In the 2D layered structure, three ligands L and three metal Cd atoms were connected to each other to form pores with a pore diameter of 10.26Å ((e)). In addition, the structure of compound 2 contained two types of hydrogen bonds: (i) NH⋯O: N1-H1C⋯O3#6 (#6 -x+1, -y+1, -z+1); (ii) OH⋯O: O5-H5B⋯O1W#7 (#7 x, -y+3/2, z+1/2), O5-H5C⋯O3#8 (#8 -x+1, y+1/2, -z+3/2), O1W-H1A⋯O4#9 (#9 -x+1, y+1/2, -z+1/2). The detailed hydrogen bonds were listed in .

[PbL] (3) X-ray single crystal analysis manifested that compound 3 crystallized in monoclinic system with P2 1/c space group. The molecular structure contained one Pb (II) atom and one ligand L. Each center metal Pb (II) forms a five-coordinate twisted triangle double with four oxygen atoms (O1#1, O2#2, O3, O4) and one nitrogen atom (N1#3) from the ligand L ( (a)). Among them, the coordination mode of the ligand L is μ4-η2η1η1η1, in which O3 and O4 took a bidentate coordination mode while O1, O2 and N1 adopt a monodentate coordination mode ((b)). The bond length of the PbO bond ranged from 1.99(2) to 2.26(3) Å, the bond length of the PbN bond was 2.23(3) Å. This is similar to the range reported in the literature for PbO bonds (2.330(7)-2.422(4)Å) and PbN bonds (2.2469(3)Å) .

UV-Vis spectra

  was the UV-Vis spectra of the compounds 1-3 and ligand L. For compound 1, the absorption bands appearing at 217nm and 262nm are from ligand (LLCT) transitions. The absorption band at 307nm was attributed to the ligand-to-metal transition (LMCT), while the metal d-d* transition (MMCT) has three absorption bands, which occur at 557, 616 and 1022nm, respectively. For compound 2, the absorption bands appearing at 221nm and 256nm were assigned to the (LLCT) transition of the ligand. The band at 310nm was assigned to a ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transition. For compound 3, the absorption bands at 222nm and 255nm are attributed to the (LLCT) transition of the ligand. The band at 308nm was assigned to a ligand-to-metal (LMCT) transition. However, the compound 2 have no absorption band between 400 and 1500nm, probably because the d orbital electrons of the central metal Cd (II) was full and therefore no d-d* transitions can occur. We found that the absorption bands at 200-300nm for 1-3 were almost the same due to the same ligand ( (L)) and the absorption bands at 300-1400nm are significantly different due to the different metals. The detailed bands for the ligand L compounds 1-3 are listed in .

Thermal analysis

  demonstrated the TG curves of the compounds 1-3. For compound 1, the first stage of weight loss occurred at 30-180°C, the actual weight loss was 12.81% (theoretical weight loss: 12.24%), corresponding to the loss of four lattice H2O. The second stage of weight loss occurred at 180-240°C, the actual weightless was 17.60% (theoretical weight loss: 18.36%), corresponding to the losing of two coordinated H2O. The third weightless stage occurred at 240-800°C, corresponding to the partial collapse of the ligand L. For compound 2, the first stage of weight loss occurred at 30-255°C and the actual weight loss was 11.71% (theoretical weight loss: 11.00%), corresponding to losing of a coordinated H2O and a lattice H2O. The second stage of weight loss occurred at 255-600°C, the actual weight loss was 58.82% (theoretical weight loss: 60.92%), corresponding to the ligand L skeleton collapsed, the final residue is cadmium oxide. For compound 3, the first weightless stage occurred at 30-600°C and the actual weight loss was 52.77%, corresponding to the partial collapse of the ligand L. Comparing the weightlessness of compounds 1-3, the thermal decomposition temperatures were 100°C, 250°C and 330°C, respectively. Therefore, in the three compounds, 3 had the best thermal stability and 1 had the worst thermal stability.

SOD activity

  shows the results of the SOD activity test for the seven compounds. We summarize the results in  . It is found from  that IC50 values of 1-7 were 10.2, 2.7, 5.9, 2.6, 20.34, 4.2, 7.2mg/L, respectively. It was clearly observed that compound 2 has the better SOD activity. This was because that coordination modes between metal and ligand, as well as the different metal center attached to the carboxyl group of the ligand were different.

cln_elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st125">Conclusions</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0160" view="all">In this work, we successfully synthesized three new superoxide dismutase mimics, [CoL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·2H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), [CdL(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (<ce:bold>2</ce:bold>) and [PbL] (<ce:bold>3</ce:bold>) under hydrothermal conditions by using the reaction of transition metal salts and 5-aminoisophthalic acid (L). Single crystal diffraction analysis reveal that compounds <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> and <ce:bold>3</ce:bold> have a 3D network structures. Three kinds of the mimic compounds were tested for SOD activity by the pyrogallol method. The minimum IC<ce:inf loc="post">50</ce:inf> value of the three mimic enzymes was 2.7 mg/L and the maximum value was 10.2 mg/L, which was less than the international standard value (32 mg/L). These results manifested that they had better SOD activity, that is, anti-ROS activity. Through the experiments, we not only added a new SOD mimetic—CdSODs, but also analyze the difference in coordination mode, which may affect the anti-ROS activity. This may provide some valuable information for future anti-aging research.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this work, we successfully synthesized three new superoxide dismutase mimics, [CoL(H2O)]⋅2H2O (1), [CdL(H2O)]⋅H2O (2) and [PbL] (3) under hydrothermal conditions by using the reaction of transition metal salts and 5-aminoisophthalic acid (L). Single crystal diffraction analysis reveal that compounds 2 and 3 have a 3D network structures. Three kinds of the mimic compounds were tested for SOD activity by the pyrogallol method. The minimum IC50 value of the three mimic enzymes was 2.7mg/L and the maximum value was 10.2mg/L, which was less than the international standard value (32mg/L). These results manifested that they had better SOD activity, that is, anti-ROS activity. Through the experiments, we not only added a new SOD mimetic-CdSODs, but also analyze the difference in coordination mode, which may affect the anti-ROS activity. This may provide some valuable information for future anti-aging research.
